bibl.title: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to Henry Rose Carter, January 22, 1921

div1.p: Lyster requests Carter's comments on a circular for the fish campaign and on the Rockefeller Foundation's methods in the Latin American yellow fever campaigns.

MEXICO AND CENTRAL AMERICA
Mexico, D. F.,
January 22nd 1921.
My Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Am enclosing a copy of a circular of a fish
campaign we have adopted for use in Mexico and Central America, & will
be glad to have any comments that you are apt to make.

The President of Mexico has just signed an Acuerdo
creating a “Comisión Especial de la campana contre la Fiebre Amarilla”
under the Department of Public Healths copy of which is enclosed; also
be glad to have your comments as to this method of campaign in Latin
American countries.

When in Salvador in 1919, I was hard pressed for a
method which would more or less unite all the Republics of Central
America under one Director and thus assist in carrying out the general
policy of Dr. Gorgas.

Acuerdos along the lines of the Salvador one which
is enclosed, have been issued by the Presidents of Salvador, Nicaragua,
Honduras, and Guatemala, in the order named, and now by the President
of Mexico.

So far, we have not run across any snags that were
not covered by the Acuerdo; as you will note, we work absolutely as a
dependency of the Consejo de Salubridad of each country.

Am very sorry to hear that you broke your ankle.
I do hope no complications have resulted, and that you are around again
on both feet. Congratulations on your brilliant work in Peru. Best
regards to you and Miss Laura.
